awd_titl_txt: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Korea
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds Tyler James Volkoff of University of California, Berkeley to conduct a research project, entitled "Numerical studies of static and dynamical properties of liquid helium in aperture arrays," during the summer of 2012 at Konkuk University in Seoul, South Korea.  The host scientist is Yongkyung Kwon.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project drives from the use of numerical simulation to analyze a dynamical phase transition in liquid helium when driven through an array of nanoscale apertures by an external driving force. A Monte Carlo algorithm is used to sample estimators of relevant thermodynamic quantities and an order parameter for the transition is derived and interpreted.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language.   These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

por.por_cntn:
Project Title: "Path-integral Monte Carlo studies of static and dynamic properties of liquid 4He in nanoaperture arrays"

Host/Collaborator: Yongkyung Kwon, Dept. of Physics, Konkuk University, Seoul, ROK

The purpose of this research was to conduct numerical simulations (using a path-integral Monte Carlo algorithm) of static and dynamic properties of liquid 4He reservoirs separated by an arrays of nanometer-sized apertures. Global and local superfluid densities and bulk healing lengths were calculated for a variety of aperture arrays. In addition, a path-integral Monte Carlo estimator for local vorticity was derived in order to analyze circulation in the aperture array system. These simulations constitute the first quantum Monte Carlo numerical analyses of this system. Our results give insight into the mechanism of weak-link formation between reservoirs of liquid 4He, in particular they are applicable to a dynamical phase transition between two different regimes of driven superfluid flow (below the normal/superfluid transition temperature) which has been experimentally observed in this system.

The results of this project are potentially useful for the engineering of tunable liquid helium technology. The research was conducted as part of a program (NSF EAPSI) fostering collaboration between graduate students in the USA and researchers in East Asia and was carried out at Konkuk University in Seoul, Korea.
